coredata.dc:title: Temperature and concentration dependence of orientational correlations of nitrate ions in Cu (NO3)2 aqueous solutions
coredata.dc:creator: Fontana, M.P.
Rosi, B.
Micali, N.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We report new results on the dynamics of orientational correlations of molecules in highly concentrated aqueous solutions of Cu (NO3)2. We determined both single-particle and pair reorientational relaxation times of the nitrate ion as a function of concentration and temperature by coupled Raman and depolarized Rayleigh wing spectroscopy measurement. The ratio of relaxation times features a non-monotonic behavior at room temperature as a function of concentration; at high and low temperatures the anomaly disappears.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: volume 185, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 October 199! and N. Micali Istituto di Tecniche Spetiroscopiche del CNR, Messina, Italy Received 28 June 1991; in final form 13August1991 We report new results on the dynamics of orientational correlations of molecules in highly concentrated aqueous solutions of Cu(N03 )~. We determined both single-particle and pair reorientational relaxation times of the nitrate ion as a function of con- centration and temperature by coupled Reman and depolarized Rayleigh wing spectroscopy measurements. The ratio of relaxa- tion times features a non-monotonie behavior at room temperature as a function of concentration; at high and low temperatures the anomaly disappears. interactions are expected to lead to quite a strong in- terplay between local order and molecular dynamics. The measurement of g2 is generally difficult, and such determinations are rare in the literature. The diffi- culties arise from the necessity of using different ex- perimental techniques to obtain both z~ and i~i si- multaneously. As far as we know, no experimental determination of g2 as a function of mean interpar- tide distance exists. In this Letter, we report the first direct measure- ment of g2 and its dependence on average intermo- lecular separation and on temperature. This result was achieved by studying the reorientations of the nitrate ion in aqueous solutions of Cu(NO3)2. The single-particle reorientational correlation function C~(t) and the related relaxation time were deter- mined by fluctuation Raman spectroscopy (FRS) ~ on the 1050 cm line due to the totally symmetric For general information and bibliography on fluctuation light scattering spectroscopy and stochastic molecular dynamics in fluids see ref. [I]. 1. Introduction When considering Brownian molecular dynamics in a fluid it is generally assumed, and found, that the single-particle motion as characterized by the sin- gle-particle reorientational relaxation time r[ should be swifter than the correlated motion of mo- lecular pairs as characterized by the pair reorien- tational relaxation time r~. In fact for orientational fluctuations in a one-component fluid we have, for a symmetric top [1]: <~cos20,1 ~> (1) where g2 is the so-called Kirkwood factor and par- ameterizes the effect of static orientational correla- tions on reorientational dynamics. The angle O,~ re- fers to the polar angle between the main symmetry axes of the reference molecule 1 and molecule j. g2 is clearly an important parameter to know when studying molecular Brownian motion, especially in the so-called associated fluids, where intermolecular 0009-26t4/91/$ 03.50 IC 1991 Elsevier Science Publishers BY. All rights reserved. 421 Temperature and concentration dependence of orientational correlations of nitrate ions in Cu(N03)2 aqueous solutions M.P. Fontana, B. Rosi Dipartimento di Fis,ca and Consorzio INFM Universira di Panna. Parma, Italy Volume 185, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 October 1991 ing the ratio of the normalized Fourier transforms of 11,0(w) and Jan,s(C0)=.IVH(W), where l~0=Ivv llv~. l~ and anis are the isotropic and anisotropic scattering intensities. The relaxation time t~ was obtained from the slope of the plot of the logarithm of the ratio versus time. The z~ values were also obtained by the convolution method, assuming a simple exponential law for the correlation function. The values obtained by both methods are in good agreement. For further details on procedures and data analysis we refer the reader to ref. [4]. The DRW spectrum is connected to the aniso- tropic fluctuations of the average molecular polar- izability, and is therefore sensitive to pair reorien- tational correlations of all the molecules which contribute to the local polarizability. Thus in a mul- ticomponent system it is not easy to separate the contribution of the specific molecular species of in- terest. As we shall see, the contribution of the nitrate ion was clearly distinguishable from the others and was found to be proportional to the solute concen- tration in the low concentration range. The DRWS measurements were performed using the new SUPRA DMDP 2000 very high resolution monochromator system [51. Such an instrument has an exceptionally large dynamic range in spectral res- olution, allowing the study of both the ordinary Raman and the Rayleigh Brillouin spectral ranges. The DRW spectra were taken using an instrumental bandpass of 0.01 cm and fitted using a Minuit least-squares routine. Particular care was taken in ensuring that the best fit corresponded to the true minimum in parameter space. We found that the spectrum could be fitted by two Lorentzians plus a Gaussian to simulate the central elastic compo- nent. In fig. 1 we give an example of a typical fit. The relaxation time z~ was then obtained using the re- lationship r~?=(itcA)~, where J is the full width at half maximum (in cm~) of the appropriate Lorentzian component. One of the components could be assigned to water molecules, both from the value of the corresponding relaxation time and from its value [4]. The other component we assumed to be dominated by the nitrate ion, given its large and strongly anisotropic polarizability. The measurements were performed at the tem- peratures of 10, 23 and 75 C using a Harney Miller stretching mode of the nitrate ion. The pair corre- lation function C~(t) and the related relaxation time were determined by depolarized Rayleigh wing spec- troscopy (DRWS). Measurements were performed as a function of nitrate concentration from 0.001 M (0.5 M for DRWS) to saturation and at three dif- ferent temperatures (10, 23, 75 C). The results are quite surprising. Only at 75 C does the behavior of r~ /r~ appear to be normal, i.e. a monotonie decrease towards unity as the concentra- tion is reduced, reflecting the proportionality to the solute-connected shear viscosity [2]. At room tem- perature we find an unexpected minimum and max- imum in the ratio, and at 10 C we find that the ratio actually increases as the concentration is reduced. 2. Experimental procedures and data analysis Stock solutions of Cu(N03)2 were prepared by standard methods. Concentration was varied by suc- cessive dilutions. Particular care was taken in max- imizing optical quality by multiple filtration. This was essential for the DRW measurements (for de- tails see ref. [3]). The light scattering experiments were performed on two separate spectrometers. One was a standard, computer-controlled, Raman spectrometer. Most of the Raman measurements were performed on this instrument. For both spectrometers the excitation wavelength (488 nm) was chosen to be in the region of maximum transparency of the solution. Incident power was kept below 50 mW, in order to avoid tur- bulence and bubbles in the liquid, and the signal was maximized by having the beam propagate parallel to the entrance slit of the monochromators. Raman spectra were taken with a spectral bandpass of 1 cm . Since the 1050 cm~ line is strongly polarized (depolarization ratio p~ 10_2), in order to have comparable statistics the integration time in the VH (depolarized) scattering geometry was 10 times longer than for the VY (polarized) geometry. The reorientational correlation function C~(t) for NO~ rotational fluctuations was determined by tak 422 Volume 185, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEUERS 25 October 1991 5000 4000 3000 2000 10 20 u ci u 1.5 s V V V I ~ o 1.0 D V D o 0.5 D so D b V 0.0 6 8 10 12 14 o alA) 16 cm-1 Fig. I. Typical DRW spectrum obtained for the 1 M solution at 23 C. The solid line is the best fit as described in the text. variable-temperature optical cell. Temperature sta- bility was within 0.5 C. As a check, some of the Rarnan spectra were also taken using the SOPRA system. The results were similar to the other Raman data. Finally, for each concentration point the FRS and the DRWS exper- iments were repeated three times, to check repro- ducibility. 3. Results and discussion For a one-component molecular fluid, the ratio z?/z~ is proportional to the Kirkwood factor g2. For a multicomponent system, the direct identification of the ratio with g2 is not possible. However if, as in our case, among the many possible pair correlations one can isolate experimentally the relaxation times corresponding to the reorientational correlations of a specific species, then the ratio could describe a partial g2 factor [6], i.e. it should be connected to the long-time limit of the orientational space cor- relations of the nitrate ions in the solution. The par- tial g2 factor thus obtained is plotted in fig. 2 for the Fig. 2. Dependence of nitrate g2 factor on mean interionic sepa- ration, for T=1O C ( ); 23 C (E); 75 C (T). The experi- mental errors are indicated by tise error bars on the point for 23 C at a= 10 A. three temperatures we have investigated. These data can be used to investigate the func- tional behavior g2(a), where a is the average inter- ionic separation. Furthermore, if we assume that the major contribution to g2 comes from the first shell of ions surrounding the reference ion, then a~R, the upper limit of the integral over all shells which con- tribute to g2 thus the function g2 (a) should ap- proximate g2(R). Such a commonly made assump- tion is qualitatively reasonable; however, it is not supported by computer simulation studies [7] for a hard-sphere fluid, which alone actually determine a functional dependence of g2 on R. In fact, if G(r) is the pair distribution function of the molecules, we have [7] g2= limg2(R), (2) where g2(R)=l+4~pJr2G(r)dr, (3) 423 L volume 185, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 October 1991 p being the number density. In this framework then the data of fig. 2 should only qualitatively approxi- mate the function g2 (R). However, even with these qualifications, this would be the first experimental determination of such behavior. In any case, the data of fig. 2 are striking. In prin- ciple, what we expect is a high value of g2 at small a, where collective effects should be more important, and a monotonic decrease toward unity as a in- creases and r~ *r~. This is in fact the behavior ob- served at 75 C. At room temperature however, g2 features a star- tling deviation from the monotonic behavior, namely it goes through a minimum and a subsequent well pronounced maximum before reducing to the high- temperature behavior at large a. An oscillation of this type was predicted by computer simulation [7] and is ascribed to anti-phase correlations of the succes- sive shells which contribute to g2. In our case such behavior may be due to the fact that, as a is reduced, more than one nitrate shell will contribute to g2. This may be so, but we must not forget that we are dealing with a two-component system; as a is varied, the number of water molecules between nitrate ions also varies, and this may strongly influence the local water structure and thus the cage of water molecules sur- rounding a given nitrate ion. That this might be a more likely explanation is confirmed by the puzzling 10 C data. In this case the behavior is just the op- posite of what is expected. Why should collective ef- fects appear to be more important at large a? To try to interpret this result, let us recall that our solution belongs to a class of liqutd electrolytes with peculiar local structural behavior, which has been extensively studied by a variety of macroscopic, structural and dynamical experimental techniques [8]. Substan- tially it appears that in these electrolytes there is a competition between the local structure of water, which dominates at concentrations up to about 0.1 Csat, and a new structure, related to the solute, and which becomes increasingly important as concentra- tion is raised towards saturation. In the intermediate concentration range of O.lCsatO.3Csat the two local structures are energetically (in terms of free energy) equivalent, and this leads to strong fluctuations. These may be the origin of the decrease in g2 at room temperature for a< 10 k, and its successive increase as a becomes even smaller. From this point of view it may be useful to con- sider the results we have obtained for aqueous so- lutions of Ca(N03)2. Such a solute is similar to Cu(N03)2, but does not show any of the anomalies we have found in Cu(N03)2 and other electrolytes in this or in other experiments. Thus we may use it as a sort of zero indicator in the present experi- ment. For Ca(N03 )2 we find no anomalies ing2 (a), which turns out to be foughly constant at room tem- perature, with an average value slightly above I, in agreement with other experiments [9]. We may con- clude that the anomalies we observe are specific of the local structuring effects present in the Cu(N03)2 type of strong II I electrolytes. An analysis of the actual values of r, at 10 C shows that they are consistently smaller, especially at high concentrations, than is the case at higher tempera- tures. This is the opposite of what should normally happen. Let us recall, however, that at high concen- tration in this type of electrolyte, inelastic neutron scattering data show the disappearance (or at least total damping) of the low-frequency vibrational modes associated with the fluctuating hydrogen bond network characteristic of the water structure [10]. This situation is favored by lower temperatures. since it is due to non-entropic (i.e. energy) contributions to the free energy of the system. Thus at high con- centrations at 10 C the g2 value will tend to unity since the hydrogen bond glue which dominated both single-particle and collective reorientations is missing: z, will be faster and t,~ *;. As the mean in- terionic distance is increased, the hydrogen bond glue is restored and g2 increases. At 75 C the destructuring and structuring effects of the solute are minimized, the entropie terms dom- inate the stochastic dynamic and the g2 (a) behavior is essentially normal. In this framework the reason for the anomalous behavior of g2(a) at 23 C ap- pears to be clear, at least qualitatively. For large a, the behavior follows the normal high-temperature behavior. When the solute concentration becomes sufficiently high however, its destructuring effects on the fluctuating hydrogen bond network decrease pair correlations, and g2 decreases. At concentrations close to saturation, the new local structure starts to impose its own influence and collective effects make g2 in. crease again. Such an increase is not observed at 10 C. This may be due to the fact that we could not 424 Volume 185, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 25 October 1991 with the Cu2~ ion. Preliminary data taken using the 514.5 nm argon laser line do not show any appre- ciable difference in the results. However, such stud- ies need to be done more thoroughly. These measurements we propose to do. Whatever the final explanation of the peculiar effects we have observed, we feel that they definitely show the in- adequacy of the decoupling approximations we are forced to use to interpret the data. Since the com- plete expressions for g2 in a two-component system are too complex to be useful [11] we feel a molec- ular dynamics simulation of reorientational fluctua- tions in aqueous solutions is necessary to guide the experimentalist in the interpretion of data such as those presented in this work. Mol. Struct. 113(1984) 239. [9] M. Whittle and J.H.R. Clarke, Chem. Phys. Letters 98 (1983) 172; R.A. Carpio, M. Mehicic and E. Yeager, J. Chem. Phys. 74 (1981) 2778. 1 10] G. Maisano, P. Migliardo, M.P. Fontana, MC. Bellissent- Funel andA.J. Dianoux, J. Phys.C 18(1985)1115. [11] G.D.J. Phillies and D. Kivelson, J. Chem. Phys. 71(1979) 2575. study DRWS at the same high molarities possible at room temperature due to the lower solubility at 10 C. However, one would expect that at 10 C the final rise in g2 should take place at lower concentrations than is the case for room temperature. We have no explanation for this. We feel, however, that this is further indication of the very delicate balance be- tween opposing effects and interactions which de- termines the reorientational dynamics in this class of aqueous solutions. 4. Conclusions In as much as the approximation g2 (a) ~g2 (R) is reasonable, we have determined the R behavior of g2, and found experimental evidence for an anom- alous, non-monotonie behavior. This, however, takes place only for room-temperature solutions and may be seen as the effect of a delicate equilibrium be- tween local structuring effects of water and solute molecules. This is confirmed by the normal behavior ofg2 (a) at 75 C and the behavior at 10 C. For this latter case, however, we do not feel that we have a satisfactory explanation. Further measurements may be necessary; in particular, a more detailed study of the temperature dependence of z~ and z~ at high con- centrations. Also, in the scattering law of quasi-elas- tic neutron scattering one should observe a kind of coherence narrowing in correspondence with the maximum in g2(a) in the room-temperature solu- tions, i.e. for concentrations of about 1 to 2 M one should observe a dip in the quasielastic half width for exchanged wave vectors of ~0.3 A . Finally, although we feel that the high anisotropy and polar- izability of the nitrate ion justifies our assumption that the DRWS is mainly due to it, such assumption should be tested by repeating the measurements at different laser wavelengths, in order to test for ef- fects due to the changing of the resonance condition 425 oncentrations close to saturation, the new local structure starts to impose its own influence and collective effects make g2 in. crease again. Such an increase is not observed at 10 C. This may be due to the fact that we could not 424 Volume 185, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 25 October 1991 with the Cu2~ ion. Preliminary data taken using the 514.5 nm argon laser line do not show any appre- ciable difference in the results. However, such stud- ies need to be done more thoroughly. These measurements we propose to do. Whatever the final explanation of the peculiar effects we have observed, we feel that they definitely show the in- adequacy of the decoupling approximations we are forced to use to interpret the data. Since the com- plete expressions for g2 in a two-component system are too complex to be useful [11] we feel a molec- ular dynamics simulation of reorientational fluctua- tions in aqueous solutions is necessary to guide the experimentalist in the interpretion of data such as those presented in this work. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We report new results on the dynamics of orientational correlations of molecules in highly concentrated aqueous solutions of Cu (NO3)2. We determined both single-particle and pair reorientational relaxation times of the nitrate ion as a function of concentration and temperature by coupled Raman and depolarized Rayleigh wing spectroscopy measurement. The ratio of relaxation times features a non-monotonic behavior at room temperature as a function of concentration; at high and low temperatures the anomaly disappears.
